published_attributes.title: Radical Candor course - what's in it for you
published_attributes.serialized_body:
This course is for you if: You are a Newbie willing to immerse into Netguru feedback culture and get to know some practical tips and tools for giving and receiving feedback?

OR

You are a new Leader participating in the Leader's Onboarding Program willing to refresh or learn how to be a feedback pro and foster a transparent and feedback friendly environment in your team.

OR

You are a feedback curious Netgural, no matter the team or seniority, willing to consolidate your knowledge around feedback and maybe learn something new.

published_attributes.title: Feedback - Netguru big picture
published_attributes.serialized_body:
The feedback culture at Netguru is closely connected to and stems from the following Netguru values:

1. Build an inclusive, transparent and socially responsible culture (here is Wiktor Schmidt's - one of Netguru's co-founders - take on this value)

At the heart of a transparent company culture is feedback, namely a feedback friendly environment, where people are encouraged to share their thoughts and have a say as well as open to other opinions. A culture where business decisions are openly discussed and often consulted with the Team.

2. Take ownership and question the status quo in a constructive manner (here is Wiktor Schmidt's - one of Netguru's co-founders - take on this value)

Netguru is a place where ways of doing things or processes are not set in stone. A place where, if you see something isn't working or could be done better in a different way, feel free to propose your ideas for changes. 

3. One extra, unspoken and unwritten value - always assume good intentions

This one is essential when it comes to receiving feedback. It's easy to fall into the trap of being defensive, assuming that someone is trying to attack us or question our expertise when receiving critical or redirecting feedback. Instead, it's much easier if we assume that the person giving feedback doesn't have bad intentions but wants to help us, give advice on how we could do things differently.

published_attributes.title: Feedback - Netguru big picture - example 1
published_attributes.serialized_body:
AMA (Ask me anything) events: monthly live events, usually run on Zoom, where Netguru Core Team members answer questions from the Team. Anyone can ask a question via a dedicated sli.do survey. The questions are upvoted/ downvoted for a week or so and then the ones with the most upvotes are answered live.

If you're you'd like to watch the latest AMA events, you can find them here. There's also a dedicated #ama Slack channel.

published_attributes.title: Why to ask for and give feedback - Johari Window
published_attributes.serialized_body:
The above graph illustrates Johari Window which, among others, can be used to explain the importance of feedback.

First things first, let's take a look at all the quadrants:

PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE - what others know about me and what I know about myself - e.g. when public speaking I tend to speak slowly.
PRIVATE KNOWLEDGE - what others don't know about me but I know and am aware about myself - e.g. public speaking makes me very nervous even though it doesn't show. 
UNKNOWN - others don't know about me and I don't know about myself - these would be situations I've never been in, usually extreme ones. e.g. Earthquake - I have no idea if I would panic and break down or stay calm and coordinate a rescue mission. 
BLIND SPOT - probably the most important quadrant in terms of feedback - what others know about me but I have no idea about - e.g. when public speaking I tend to repeat the word "actually" too often. It's annoying to people listening to me, but I have no idea about it... until someone gives me feedback!

published_attributes.title: Why to ask for and give feedback - Blind Spots
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Feedback may be considered a gift, when you let the person narrow down the “blind spot” quadrant in favour of the “public knowledge” quadrant.

You will not change people but you can help them change their behaviours (if they wish) if you give feedback.

It refers to both positive (reinforcing) and negative (redirecting) feedback. 

Positive feedback for eliminating blind spots

Often times, when the impostor syndrome kicks in, we're not aware that we're great at something and could do more of it and even consider it our strength - e.g. empathy and the ability to put myself in someone else's shoes. Let's say that I never considered it my strength but thanks to feedback I learnt about it and now use this skill more consciously (as a UX designer). 

Critical feedback for eliminating blind spots

Critical (reinforcing) feedback can be a powerful tool to stimulate growth. There's some area that would make you an even better expert e.g. system thinking and software architecture may be something that you are currently lacking but you're not aware of (your blind spot). Knowing that, it's your decision what to do about it.

TIP: ask for and give feedback regularly to identify blind spots (yours and others).

published_attributes.title: Blind Spots - self-reflection
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Self-reflection:

Take a few minutes to remember a situation when someone gave you feedback that eliminated your blind spot. Was it positive or negative feedback? What was it? What have you done about it? How did you feel when you received this piece of feedback?

How about a situation when you gave someone feedback that eliminated their blind spot? Was it positive or negative feedback? What was it? How did they take it? What have they done about it? How did you feel when you gave this piece of feedback?

published_attributes.title: Why to ask for and give feedback - Public Knowledge
published_attributes.serialized_body:
In addition to eliminating blind spots and as a result expanding the "public knowledge" quadrant, you may give feedback is the so called “private knowledge”. Manipulating this quadrant requires some vulnerability on your side but help other's work with you more efficiently.

If you're a leader a leader's expose or leader's readme (there's a separate Leaders' Onboarding course dedicated to it) may do the job. If you're not a leader you may still draft and share with your team your personal "readme" that could include such areas as:

  • your core values (e.g. teamwork, transparency, mission)
  • your personality type (e.g. DISC, 16 personalities)
  • your strengths and superpowers (e.g. Gallup Strengths)
  • your development goals
  • fun fact about you
  • your working habits
  • your communication style
  • things people might misunderstand about you
  • your Achilles hill

published_attributes.title: Radical Candor in a nutshell
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Here are all of the feedback behaviors described by Kim in the video. The toxic ones seem obvious at first glance but we all might have fallen into the trap of behaving in such ways sometimes. 

RUINOUS EMPATHY - when you're a newly promoted leader and it's hard to give radically candid feedback to someone who has recently been your peer. Or you're more friends than colleagues with your team mate.
MANIPULATIVE INSINCERITY - if you've been before in an environment that didn't promote open and honest feedback, it may seem a better solution to say nothing than to react and potentially get punished. Even if it's against your core values. 
OBNOXIOUS AGGRESSION - you may have good intentions to be open and honest but give feedback a little bit too directly and harsh. What seems fine by you, may not necessarily be okey for someone a little bit more vulnerable.

It definitely takes time and conscious effort to consistently land in the RADICAL CANDOR quadrant. Having built solid and healthy relationships, being able to challenge people in a friendly, respectful and constructive way so that instead of running away, they actually end up finding your feedback a gift. Sometimes a missing puzzle in their development and growth.

published_attributes.title: Radical Candor - self-reflection
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Self-reflection:

Take a few minutes to think about what you could do in order to cross the sometimes thin line between these three feedback behaviors - RUINOUS EMPATHY, MANIPULATIVE INSINCERITY, OBNOXIOUS AGGRESSION - and RADICAL CANDOR. What might have been blocking you from giving radically candid feedback in the past? How could you overcome it in the future?

published_attributes.title: Types of feedback
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Types of feedback:

1. REINFORCING or POSITIVE FEEDBACK

Sometimes highly underutilized. Why? Maybe because of the assumption that there's no need to praise for something so obvious - doing our job well, which is, by the way, what we get paid for.

What is the role of reinforcing feedback? Serve as a benchmark both for the recipient and the whole team. It sends a clear message: "well done, let's do more of this, it helps us achieve results". What is more, we're very often unaware of our strengths and take them for granted. Reinforcing feedback is a way of eliminating such blind spots.

In addition, reinforcing feedback is always super motivating and is a form of recognition. It builds a sense of connection and self-esteem. Tip from Kim Scott - author of Radical Candor - care more about giving positive feedback than negative!

Finally, there's a less obvious but essential role of reinforcing feedback. It's a building block of a healthy and positive professional relationship. A relationship that's necessary for giving redirecting feedback. In other words, reinforcing feedback builds ground for more challenging, constructive feedback.

published_attributes.title: Types of feedback
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Types of feedback:

2. REDIRECTING or NEGATIVE FEEDBACK

An indispensable element of learning. We all make mistakes, we all have our shortcomings and imperfections, false assumptions, things we haven't (un)learnt but should.

What are the biggest challenges here when you give it? ONE - not being afraid to give it. TWO - finding the sweet spot. The sweet spot between being too direct and hurting the other person and being too soft and sugarcoating it too much.

The biggest challenge of all, however, is building the capacity for receiving redirecting feedback. Because it's always hard when someone tells us we could be doing something differently. It requires putting our ego aside for a while, assuming good intentions of the other person (it's not easy for them as well by the way) and just then deciding what we want to do about it.

published_attributes.title: Receiving negative feedback
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Here are some tips from Kim Scott and Russ Lareway on how to take feedback like a boss:

Episode overview - Take Feedback Like a Boss:

Taking feedback well is tricky — it’s completely natural to have a defensive reaction when someone tells you how you can improve. In today’s episode, Kim and Russ offer advice for getting past that defensive reaction to encourage more feedback and get more out of it.

Russ starts with a behind-the-scenes of the podcast story. He was telling a story during a previous recording that ended up playing to common gender stereotypes. Kim gave him feedback during the recording, but Russ had a defensive, threat response reaction. He realized this and wished he had reacted differently.

Russ mentions how good Kim is at taking feedback well, how quickly she can get over a defensive reaction and get to the good stuff. Kim chalks it up to Granny Alice and tells a story about advice Granny Alice gave her as a child. Kim decided early on to learn from feedback and use it to become a better human being.

This episode also talks about what to do if you disagree with feedback you’ve been given. “Reward the Candor” means showing you appreciate that the person told you what they think, but that doesn’t mean you have to accept it. Kim and Russ give advice for how to show you Care Personally and Challenge Directly in this circumstance. Take some time to reflect and find a piece of the feedback you agree with.

What is it that I’m doing that’s causing him to think this? Where is this coming from?

Recognize the part that you agree with, and explain why you disagree with the rest.

Extra reading: The Blog: Radical Reading - 6 Tips for Taking Feedback Well

published_attributes.title: Redirecting feedback - self-reflection
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Self-reflection:

Take a few minutes to think about your emotions when you receive redirecting feedback. Do you feel discredited or personally attacked? Find a redirecting piece of feedback that you have received from your leader or team mate and try to distance yourself from such emotions and take it as it is, assuming good intentions.

published_attributes.title: Asking for feedback
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Asking for feedback may be tricky. The wording you use usually has direct correlation with the quantity and quality of responses. 

Quick tips:
  1. Less is more: ask fewer people but the ones you closely cooperate with and can get quality feedback from.
  2. Personalize and include specific details in your the feedback request. When using Bridge, take time to clarify what contexts you're asking feedback about. Nice to do - write personal Slack request to all the people you want feedback from with reasoning why you find their feedback valuable.

Here's a short video from Jacob Morgan about what questions to ask in order to get better feedback:

published_attributes.title: How to give feedback
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Have you ever given or received such feedback?

1. Positive feedback:

"I love working with you! You're always responsive and helpful".

"She's a great person. Good job on the last project!"

"You're very patient and friendly. I hope we will have a chance to work together in the future".

"I think your reliable."

2. Critical feedback:

"He's usually too reserved. Has extensive technical knowledge but often keeps it to himself".

"You're often late to meetings and it's frustrating to the team".

"She keeps interrupting people. It's so annoying."

"You should be more proactive."

 Next steps:

Giving meaningful feedback that helps people grow isn't easy. Let's now focus on how to become better at it by using a proven structure and avoiding blur words.

Giving meaningful feedback that helps people grow isn't easy. Let's now focus on how to become better at it by using a proven structure and avoiding blur words.

blocks.text: Have you ever given or received such feedback?
1. Positive feedback:
"I love working with you! You're always responsive and helpful".
"She's a great person. Good job on the last project!"
"You're very patient and friendly. I hope we will have a chance to work together in the future".
"I think your reliable."
2. Critical feedback:
"He's usually too reserved. Has extensive technical knowledge but often keeps it to himself".
"You're often late to meetings and it's frustrating to the team".
"She keeps interrupting people. It's so annoying."
"You should be more proactive."

published_attributes.title: How to give feedback
published_attributes.serialized_body:
So what is the secret sauce of meaningful and impactful feedback?

According to LeeAnn Renniger it's the four-part formula:
  1. Micro yes or feedback alert - get a buy-in from the person you want to share feedback with and create a sense of autonomy.
  2. Data point - specific and objective information - what and where happened.
  3. Impact - say specifically how those data point(s) impacted you.
  4. End on a question This way it's not a monologue but a joint problem-solving situation.
Simon Sinek, on the other hand, suggests using an FBI structure:
  1. Feelings - say exactly how a give situation made you feel.
  2. Behavior - the specific action that made you feel that way.
  3. Impact - what impact the situation has had on you and can have in the future if repeated.

published_attributes.title: How to give feedback
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Taking the best ideas from LeeAnn, Simon as well as the books Radical Candor and Non-violent Communication we recommend using this 5-step framework for giving redirecting feedback:

1. Feedback alert
2. Situation and behavior (data points)
3. My feelings and impact
4. Solution
5. Perspective

It's just a recommendation though. You may give great quality feedback using some other structure that works best for you.

published_attributes.title: How to give feedback
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Before going through the 5 steps of the proposed feedback structure lets start with the context.

Context: Last week you attended Sarah's case study presentation. This was the first time you attended her presentation. It was very informative and insightful. Sarah did a great job but, even though other participants didn't seem to bother, it was disturbing for you because she used a lot of swear words. Probably it was her way to make it casual and fun and maybe strengthen the message. It made it difficult for you to focus. You were thinking more of the language Sarah was using that the content itself, which was great, by the way.

Should you give Sarah feedback?

Yes! The swear words used throughout the presentation by Sarah made you feel uncomfortable. It may be Sarah's blind spot. By giving feedback you give her a chance to do something about it, or do nothing - it's her decision after all.

published_attributes.title: How to give feedback
published_attributes.serialized_body:
1. Feedback alert

Maybe Sarah has a bad day. Maybe she's super busy right now and this is not a good time. Before giving feedback its a good idea to ask if the other person is ok with it. Not only are you letting her know "this is feedback time", but also if she says yes, it's a buy-in already, a way to dismantle the defensive mechanism that kicks in when we feel in danger. In danger of losing face or that someone questions our expertise.

Her "yes" is in fact a yes to getting feedback and receiving advice. It puts you two in the Radical Candor quadrant - "I care about you, I'm going to challenge you directly but also offer help to work things out with you, if you wish". 

Feedback to Sarah:

Avoid blur words such as: unprofessional, amazing, sloppy, reliable, awesome, disengaged, unprepared.

Be specific instead and describe the situation and behaviour in detail.

published_attributes.title: How to give feedback
published_attributes.serialized_body:
3. My feelings and impact

By making it personal and giving your perspective you won't make it sound accusatory. At the end of the day, you're presenting your opinion about a given situation.

Feedback to Sarah:
TIP:

When writing feedback, write in the first person. This way you will instantly feel more connected to the person and not distance yourself from them. Finally, the person will read your feedback anyway and it will sound more like a personal piece of advice.

Avoid “You” statements such as "you insulted me" because they drive a sense of blame.

published_attributes.serialized_body:
4. Solution

Make your feedback constructive and actionable by providing a suggestion of what the person could be doing differently in the future. 

Feedback to Sarah:
TIP:

Give specific measures (ON MONDAY), not general adverbs of frequency (always, never, often), especially when you are providing feedback that may be taken as critique.

5. Perspective

Open a dialogue and ask for their perspective. Be open to the idea that you may be wrong. Or that someone simply disagrees with you. Or you were missing some important details.

published_attributes.title: Feedback FAQ
published_attributes.serialized_body:
1. Which means (medium) for giving feedback is the best? Bridge, Slack, Google form, a call?

It depends a lot on the context. Bridge works best for periodic, Performance Conversation feedback. Slack may be ok for instant feedback although sometimes it's better to jump on a quick call and have a chat. Paradoxically, it may be less time consuming than crafting good quality written feedback. Google forms are a good choice for feedback from clients because we can't use Bridge for this purpose (feedback requests outside of Netguru). 

2. When to give and expect instant feedback?

When distinctive behaviour occurs, i.e. someone has done something significant - either super good or something that leaves a lot to be desired - and it's better to address it now than wait for this person's Performance Conversation. 

3. When is periodic, Performance Conversation feedback ok?

When we have overview on someone's performance/growth over a longer period of time e.g. project work. 

4. If you're a leader, is it better to let your teammate collect feedback or to do it on their behalf?

It's best to transfer ownership for collecting feedback to your teammate. You may however assist with some tips and tricks and make sure they ask the right people.

5. My Performance Conversation is approaching. How many people should I send feedback requests in Bridge to?

Around 5 should be enough. Focus on quality, not quantity. Choose the people you have worked the most with and have quality feedback to share. Don't ask for feedback random people you have had 1 or 2 calls with. 

6. Do I need to stick to the START/STOP/CONTINUE framework?

Definitely not! This framework is for you to help. If it doesn't help, you don't need to stick to it. Focus more on the quality of your feedback.
